institute: Department of Informatics and Artificial Intelligence

homeWelcome: Welcome to the Robogames Information System!
homeP1: This site serves as an information system for the management and organization of the Robogames competition. It is intended for participant registration, team and category management, and competition workflow organization.
homeP2: The main website with information for the public, competition rules, news, and program can be found at:
homeP3: Robogames is a competition event organized by the Faculty of Applied Informatics at Tomas Bata University in Zlín since 2017. The competition takes place on the grounds of the Faculty of Applied Informatics and is intended for high school and university students, primary school pupils, members of robotics clubs, and other unorganized enthusiasts from the general public.
howToRegisterDesc: Follow these simple steps to sign up for the competition
guideStep1Desc: Register in the system or log in if you already have an account.
guideStep2Desc: Start a team or get invited to an existing one.
guideStep3Desc: In the My Team section, click the button to register for the competition.
guideStep4Desc: On the registration page, select a specific competition year and confirm.
guideStep5Desc: Add robots to your registration and choose their disciplines.
readyToStartDesc: Register today and show the world what your robots can do!

ageCatP1: Based on birth date (filled in the application), contestants will be divided into the following categories:
ageCatP3: Students and adults: over 15 years old
partsP: In addition to LEGO kits, we want to support robots built from anything as much as possible in Robogames. We want to motivate all robotics enthusiasts and students to participate regardless of whether they have enough money for "official" LEGO kits. We believe that success in the competition should depend primarily on talent, diligence, and sporting luck. We understand the concerns of "official" kit users that they might be at a disadvantage compared to other contestants, e.g., due to weaker motors or batteries. However, they can find inspiration at our competition and also connect stronger ("unofficial") components to their official kits.
teamsP: In all competitions, a multi-member team can compete with one robot. However, in case of victory, the team will receive only 1 physical prize.
regP: For each discipline, it is possible to register with one robot per team. When a team participates in multiple disciplines, it is possible to have a different robot for each discipline.
scheduleP1: Before the start of the competition, a start schedule will be developed, which contestants must follow. Failure to comply may result in penalties, up to disqualification.
scheduleP2: Contestants must undergo their competition upon the referee's call. Possible delays are allowed only for robot repairs or battery replacement.
scheduleP3: If a contestant refuses to compete upon the organizers' call, they will not be allowed to complete their discipline.
sumoP: The purpose of the competition is a confrontation between two robots trying to push their opponent off the playing surface.
max20cm: Maximum robot dimensions: footprint max. 20×20 cm, height unlimited
sumoRuleP1: The purpose of the competition is a confrontation between two robots trying to push their opponent off the playing surface.
sumoRuleP2: Robots can have unlimited height, but their footprint can be a maximum of 20×20 cm. Compliance with this rule will be checked by placing the robot into a frame with internal dimensions of 20×20 cm. The robot must pass through this frame.
sumoRuleP3: The robot can weigh a maximum of 1 kg. Weight limit will be checked before the robot enters the ring, but also after battery replacement.
sumoRuleP4: After the start of the match, the robot can increase its dimensions, e.g., by extending decoy targets.
sumoRuleP5: The robot can split into several separate parts or robots after the start. However, if any part ends up outside the ring, the robot loses.
sumoRuleP6: The robot must not use any techniques to change adhesion to the ring surface in the match, whether mechanical or chemical.
sumoRuleP7: The robot must not contaminate the ring surface. It must not release any substances (glues, oils, degreasers, smoke, fog...).
sumoRuleP8: The robot may only push the opponent. It must not use techniques for destruction, damage, or immobilization of the opponent, such as shooting, hammer blows, use of flames, electric discharges, nets, or materials winding onto wheel axles, etc.
sumoRuleP9: The Sumo ring has a diameter of 154 cm. It is made of black laminated chipboard 1 cm thick, supported by legs 4 cm high. The ring has a 5 cm wide white border. Starting lines are brown, 2 cm wide, and 20 cm apart – see dimensions in Fig. 1.
sumoRuleP10: The Sumo ring is assembled from two halves, so a joint leads through the center of the area, which is not ideally smooth.
sumoRuleP11: The match lasts a maximum of 9 minutes net time and consists of a maximum of three valid rounds, so the length of one round is 3 minutes. The winner of the round gets 1 point and the match ends when one of the robots gets 2 points.
sumoRuleP12: The match begins with the robots placed on the marked spots on the playing surface with the back side of the robot and are put into action by contestants upon the referee's signal. After switching on, the robot must not move for 5 seconds, but it is allowed to signal robot activity, for example, optically or acoustically. During the five seconds after the start of the match, contestants must step back from the playing surface at least 150 cm. If any of the robots starts moving in the first five seconds of the match start, it can be penalized by the referee, or even disqualified.
sumoRuleP13: If a robot wants to cross to the other half of the competition ring for the first time, it must turn at least 90° compared to the starting position.
sumoRuleP14: A robot loses the competition round when any part of it touches the base on which the competition surface is placed.
sumoRuleP15: If after 3 minutes in the third deciding round both robots have the same number of points, the referee can order an extension or assign a winning point for greater activity.
sumoRuleP16: If the robots are locked into each other and/or their movement does not indicate hope for a change for more than 5 seconds, the referee can order a new round.
sumoRuleP17: If one robot stops and stands for more than 5 seconds, its opponent gets 1 point and the round is ended.
sumoRuleP18: The robot moves only autonomously and no form of communication with the robot is allowed during the competition round.
sumoRuleP19: Based on the number of contestants, they are assigned to groups where they compete in "round robin" style, or only one group is created and they compete the same way.
sumoRuleP20: The winner of the entire competition is the one who gets the most points.
miniP: A variant of the Robosumo competition, whose rules are shared with this variant.
followP: The competition is won by the robot that traverses the track, implemented as a black line on a white background, in the fastest time. The track contains turns, right-angle (sharp) corners, and intersections, and the robot must traverse it from start to finish as accurately as possible.
max25cm: Maximum robot dimensions: footprint max. 25×25 cm, height unlimited
followRuleP1: The track is made of white plastic foil (used for advertising banners) measuring 280×200 cm. A 15 mm wide black line path is marked on this foil. Turns have a minimum radius of 10 cm, the smallest distance of parallel lines ("grid") of the track is 20 cm.
followRuleP2: The robot must follow the line the entire way from start to finish.
followRuleP3: If the robot leaves the line, then finds it again and does not shorten its path, the run is valid.
followRuleP4: If the robot leaves the line, then finds it again and shortens its path, the referee will declare the run invalid.
followRuleP5: Until the 3-minute time limit expires, it is possible to place the robot back at the start and begin another attempt. The resulting time is the shortest attempt's time.
followRuleP6: If the robot does not finish even once within the time limit, the referee will record only the number of checkpoints the robot passed through during its attempt and also the maximum attempt time in the results list.
followRuleP7: Robots that do not finish are penalized for each untraversed checkpoint with a fixed value (1 minute) and the resulting penalty is then added to the competition attempt.
followRuleP8: The robot moves only autonomously and no form of communication with the robot is allowed during the competition run.
followRuleP9: The contestant undergoes a "live" competition run only once and repeated attempts are not allowed.
followRuleP10: Unless otherwise stated in the registration form, robots must perform a competition attempt on both types of tracks (see below).
lego: LEGO - Robot is equipped with only one optical sensor
mcu: MCU - Robot can be equipped with several sensors
track: Track examples (the displayed pattern may not be used):
cleanerP1: The robot moves on a surface measuring 140×100 cm.
cleanerP2: The surface is made of white Sololak board, edged with 30 mm thick black electrical tape.
cleanerP3: 6 Lego® Duplo sized cubes are distributed on the surface.
cleanerP4: The robot has a total of three attempts, each three minutes long, to bring the maximum number of cubes to a defined area.
cleanerP5: The area for bringing cubes is a circular sector with a radius of 30 cm in the corner of the competition surface.
cleanerP6: The position from which the robot starts the attempt is diagonally from the area where it is supposed to bring the cubes.
cleanerP7: In the target area, there is a box at least 30 cm high, placed at a 45° angle to the playing surface edges at a distance of 10 cm.
cleanerP8: Cubes are placed randomly and their position is identical for each contestant.
cleanerP9: The robot has three minutes to pick up the cubes and bring them to the defined place. If it doesn't manage to collect all cubes in this limit, one minute is added to the attempt time for each cube the robot failed to bring.
cleanerP10: The contestant can end their attempt at any time by announcing it to the referee. The referee will record the attempt time and also the number of cubes brought.
cleanerP11: The robot whose attempt is the shortest wins.
cleanerV1: The robot only brings cubes to a defined area.
cleanerV1P1: A cube is counted if after the attempt is finished it is at least partially within its volume in the defined area.
cleanerV1P2: Cubes that the robot brings and then pushes out again are not counted.
cleanerV2: The robot throws cubes into a box.
cleanerV2P1: In the corner of the target area, instead of a box, a bin is placed into which cubes are thrown.
cleanerV2P2: The bin has dimensions 210×210×100 mm. The back side is 300 mm high.
cleanerV2P3: A cube is counted only if after the attempt is finished it is inside the bin.
